thread.title: Cross Country: Ridge girls, Voorhees boys roll at Shore Coaches Invitational
thread.title_full: Cross Country: Ridge girls, Voorhees boys roll at Shore Coaches Invitational

title: Cross Country: Ridge girls, Voorhees boys roll at Shore Coaches Invitational
text:
Cross Country: Ridge girls, Voorhees boys roll at Shore Coaches Invitational Daniel LoGiudice, @danny_logiudice 9:41 p.m. EDT October 3, 2015 Start of the Boys Varsity D race at the 2015 Shore Coaches Invitational Meet at Holmdel Park in Holmdel, NJ on October 3, 2015. (Photo: Peter Ackerman/Staff Photographe) 2 CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
HOLMDEL The Voorhees boys cross country team and the Ridge girls cross country team had a lot to be happy about on Saturday afternoon at Holmdel Park. 
Voorhees placed first in the Boys Varsity C race during the Shore Coaches Invitational with 22 points and an average time of 16:40. Ridge also placed first in the Girls Varsity B race with 61 points and an average of 19:56. 
Senior Robert Whitney and sophomore Chris Romero finished in first and second in the Varsity C race, respectively, with times of 16:13 and 16:18. Senior Brendan McGill (fourth place, 16:44), junior Evan Minor (seventh place, 16:55) and senior Matt Vira (eighth place, 17:07) also paced the Vikings. 
Senior Sophie Spring (third place, 19:32), junior Catherine Giuseffi (ninth place, 19:50), junior Claire Jones (10th place, 19:51), sophomore Caitlin Haggard (19th place, 20:11) and junior Shayna Bains (22nd place, 20:19) fueled the Red Devils. 
For the Vikings, it was an absolutely dominating performance despite the cold and rainy weather. 
“With the weather the way it was, I didn’t expect much time wise,” Whitney said. “It was a nice surprise the way we ran.” 
There was a significant drizzle throughout the day and wind at times was difficult to manage, but the Vikings adapted and came out on top. 
“The course wasn’t too bad, but in the beginning with the sloping uphill, I could feel my feet slipping a bit,” Whitney said. “Still, we had the fastest team average which is a really good indicator for the rest of the season.” 
One of the first big meets of the year, the Coaches Invitational is a good place to shine and set up for the rest of the season. The Vikings did just that. 
“I have a lot of expectations for this team,” Whitney said. “As long as we stay healthy and keep pushing, we’ll do well.” 
The Red Devils were unable to get an individual winner, but their team result was just the same as the Vikings which is all that matters to the runners 
“We wanted to work on staying in a pack, and our goal was to win,” Spring said. “We approached it like any other race.” 
Like the Vikings, the Red Devils also have set lofty expectations for themselves. They feel like Saturday’s meet was a good jumping-off point. 
“This is the first meet that we really think is important, so we had a couple good weeks of training,” Spring said. “With county and conference coming up, we have the same goal as this meet, and that’s to win.” 
Other local winners: 
Hillsborough won the Varsity A girls race with 115 points and a 20:25 average. Senior Paige Novak (eighth place, 19:40), senior Stephanie Mauer (17th, 20:14) and sophomore Chloe Wong (22nd, 20:28) paced the Raiders. 
Individually, Delaware Valley senior Hannah Bonaguidi struck gold in the A race with a time of 18:40, easily outrunning runner-up Christina Rancan of West Windsor-Plainsboro South (19:03). 
Hunterdon Central won the Varsity A-2 boys race with 96 points and a 17:00 average. Sophomore Justin Cornetta (third place, 16:15), senior Andrew Dyer (seventh, 16:53) and junior Ryan Eville (eighth, 16:55) paced the Red Devils. 
In Varsity E girls, New Providence won with 69 points and a 21:06 average. Senior Jillian Turned led the Pioneers with a fourth-place finish in 20:06. Union Catholic took second with 73 points as senior Amari Onque Shabazz crossed the line third in 20:02. 
In Varsity F girls, Pingry sophomore Anna Wood finished first in 20:32, 13 seconds ahead of runner-up Mary Lynch of Villa Walsh. Pingry was second overall with 55 points, behind Villa Walsh’s 33. 
Staff writer Daniel LoGiudice: dlogiudice@gannettnj.com 2 CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://mycj.co/1LaRTsR TOP VIDEOS
